Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Hooked it.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Tell me about it.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Oh I see. You got your individual slices of hope, dignity, confidence, self-love, justice, and harmony.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: So you eat-- read it everyday?

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: And these pan pizzas have opened up the doors to heaven?

Speaker: driver
Dialogue: How was your day, today, sir?

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Effective. But to tell you the truth, I've lost my passion for work.

Speaker: driver
Dialogue: Do you like the people you work with?

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: I work alone.

Speaker: driver
Dialogue: That's it then. That's it. I've always been alone. That's why I'm a good driver. I can handle it. See, I can think on my feet. I survive, I'm a thinker. And I can sit there in front of your house for two hours and it don't bother me. Some people can't do it! Some people are ranting and raving, "Tell them fuckin' people to get out here and get in this car, I can't-- I want a go!" Where you gonna go? You're gonna wind up back in your garage at seven o'clock at night. You ain't going nowhere. You leave your house in the morning you get back to your house in the evening. What's the big deal, right?

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: You understand the psychology of the job.

Speaker: driver
Dialogue: I do. Some guys can't adjust to it; they can't handle it.

Speaker: driver
Dialogue: You look like you're far away. Far away and thinking about other things. I'm right about that, aren't I?

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: driver
Dialogue: Well, let's just say that sometimes I'm right. Sometimes you are.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Sometimes I am. Sometimes. It's only natural.

Speaker: driver
Dialogue: It's only natural....

Speaker: driver
Dialogue: I been looking at you, and I've decided that I want to share something with you.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Okay.

Speaker: driver
Dialogue: Because your problem is you're bored. And you have a very big mind.  I am part of what I call a brain syndicate.

Speaker: driver
Dialogue: I am part of a network of minds, a group of five people who are all connected, over hundreds, even thousands of miles, through the mind. We can think with each other, think for each other. I can be driving somewhere, sleeping with a woman-- whatever it is-- and at the same time be thinking a thought in someone else's mind, far away. Running someone else's brain.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Up on the right.

Speaker: driver
Dialogue: And when you think of it, it's not so surprising that a small group of people control the whole world, is it?

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: If it's not there, I can't proceed. Tell them.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Tom. I've been waiting for an answer. I'm only in town tonight.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: What's different this time than the last time? I have to be down front...

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: ...I don't bother to call anyone else because you always take care of me.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Hold on a second, Tom. I got my hands full here.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Good. Account number 3649367, transfer to account number 96-546-38739-47825. Ask for Mr. Sanchez, tell him it's Mr. Duckman. If there are any problems, access file 673594638-IO- 98, and look at it.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Sorry Tom. But look, I know it's the playoffs. That's why I'm offering a thousand dollars for one seat...

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: ...Well let me ask you, Tom. What do I have to do to get courtside tickets for the Knicks...?

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Never mind. I gotta go.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: ...Tell them that's not my problem. I was paid for one job-- the cyclist-- not two. See you tomorrow, Marcella.

Speaker: marcella
Dialogue: Wait. I have Mr. Grocer for you.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Patch him through....

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: What do you want?

Speaker: grocer
Dialogue: I'm setting up a concern that would enable those of us in our rarefied profession to consolidate our efforts.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Like a union?

Speaker: grocer
Dialogue: Like a club. Work less, make more.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Thank you, no.

Speaker: grocer
Dialogue: We could be working together, making big money, killing important people... I'm willing to let you in on the ground floor.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: And you could be... sort of like... a father figure to me....

Speaker: grocer
Dialogue: It's a free-market evolution. You'll wake up to it... c'mon Kid. We used to run together when you were a rookie. I don't want to run against you. This thing's real. Everybody's in.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Not me. So don't paw at me with your dirty little guild.

Speaker: grocer
Dialogue: I'm gonna get you, kid.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Freeze! Police!

Speaker: husky man
Dialogue: Whatever it is that I'm doing that you don't like I'll stop doing it.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: It's not me.

Speaker: marcella
Dialogue: ...So come on back to the old oak tree, acorns. Signed, the reunion committee."

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Throw that away.

Speaker: marcella
Dialogue: This?

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Don't tease me. You know what I do for a living.

Speaker: marcella
Dialogue: It's from one of those P.O. Boxes. How was the trip?

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Tedious. I now authorize you to throw away all personal mail.

Speaker: marcella
Dialogue: All of it?

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: And not show it to me. Ever again.

Speaker: marcella
Dialogue: That's going to cost.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: I'll pay.

Speaker: marcella
Dialogue: They're not happy, sir.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: I'm not happy.

Speaker: marcella
Dialogue: They say their friend was suppose to have a heart attack and die in his sleep.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: He didn't.

Speaker: marcella
Dialogue: They blame you for the compromise.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: And they want me to make up for it.

Speaker: marcella
Dialogue: In Detroit. This weekend.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Tell them that's impossible. I need my normal lead time.

Speaker: marcella
Dialogue: They were very upset.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Would you describe their position as inflexible?

Speaker: marcella
Dialogue: Intractable, sir. You leave tonight.

Speaker: marcella
Dialogue: And sir, I also get that broken- mirror, black-cat, Friday-the- thirteenth kind of feeling about this one....

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: There's nothing to be done about it.

Speaker: marcella
Dialogue: I liquidated the last account in Zurich, and split it into two new ones in Estonia.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Good. What else? Anything interesting?

Speaker: marcella
Dialogue: Mmm, not really. But you're gonna love this one.

Speaker: marcella
Dialogue: Enough?

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Never enough.

Speaker: marcella
Dialogue: But it's a Greenpeace boat. It'd be so easy.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: I have scruples. Next.

Speaker: marcella
Dialogue: Paperwork on the Detroit thing. It's a full dossier. Very comprehensive.

Speaker: marcella
Dialogue: You should get going....

Speaker: marcella
Dialogue: Don't forget your identity.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: See you next week.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Tell Dr. Oatman I'm on my way.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: It's in Michigan. Honestly, what do I have in common with those people? Or with anyone?

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Come on.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Shouldn't you be taking notes?

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: It'll be depressing.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: I just know.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: They'll have husbands and wives and children and houses and dogs.... made themselves a part of something. And they can talk about what they do. What am I going to say?  "I killed the President of Paraguay with a fork."

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Why not. I trust you. You couldn't turn me in because of Doctor-Patient privilege... and I don't want to be "withholding"... and I know where you live.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: We're both professionals, Oatman.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: So you're saying that Ulysses-- everything he said to his queen when he came back--everything was a lie? He just wanted to fuck around?

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Mmm.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Uneasy. Dispassionate. Bored. It's just getting hard to go to work in a good mood. I'm starting to think I've been in the business too long. Last week I did a guy younger than me.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: If I show up at your door, chances are you did something to bring me there. I don't care about that stuff, anyway.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Morality.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: If I get antsy I'll kill a few small animals.

Speaker: oatman
Dialogue: Now we're making progress.

Speaker: cat
Dialogue: Meow.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Just a minute.

Speaker: cat
Dialogue: Meow!

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Food soon...

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Tuna or liver?

Speaker: cat
Dialogue: Meow.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Tuna it is.

Speaker: lardner
Dialogue: You always say that. You always say that. I'm telling you, you never met the man.

Speaker: mccullers
Dialogue: Seventeen months ago I was posting a walk in Lisbon, and he was there. He never saw me. But I saw him, though.

Speaker: lardner
Dialogue: Lisbon?

Speaker: mccullers
Dialogue: In Portugal, yes.

Speaker: lardner
Dialogue: Here's the news: He hasn't been in Portugal since '90. I know that from the file. Why don't you read the file, man?

Speaker: mccullers
Dialogue: In fact, I think I talked with him, in Bonn.

Speaker: lardner
Dialogue: You always say that. You always have to know everybody. Why don't I just take the weekend off and let you kill him. Since you two are so close.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Mein hero.

Speaker: female deejay
Dialogue: --and I'm ready for some good tunes and angry talk. Or angry tunes and good talk--

Speaker: female deejay
Dialogue: --The Cocteau Twins, though also a band of the nineties, will be aired due to the fact that they created their own language to sing by--

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: --Now that's freedom--

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: --The best I can do is a rhyme: Where are all the good men dead? In the heart or in the head? Back later....

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: What are you doing here?

Speaker: carl
Dialogue: A double shift. What's it look like?  Can I help you with something?

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: I don't think so.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Dr. Oatman. Dr. Oatman. Please pick up if you're there... It's Martin Blank. It's gone. My house. It's not here. My house is gone and now there's a 7-11 here... And that's unfortunate... You can never go home again, Dr. Oatman.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: But I guess you can shop there.

Speaker: nurse
Dialogue: Mary, your son's here.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: I bought a new rug.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: That's wonderful, Mom.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: What's a revival tent?

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: It's a place where religious people--

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Marlin Perkins and Jim!

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Jim?

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: His assistant. He acted like Marlin's son, only he wasn't. At least they never said he was... I bet they were lovers, faggots. Yes, gay lovers. Wild Kingdom my ass!

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: It's good to see you. I'm sure you're curious about what I've been doing.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: I spoke to your father the other day.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: I imagine that'd be rather difficult.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Nature made him then broke the mold.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: They told me you're taking lithium, mom.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Yes, they give me headaches. I have a headache.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: You have a headache?

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: I have a headache. You have a headache?

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: No, I don't have one.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: You don't have a headache. I have a headache.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: We had a good laugh, didn't we?

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Yeah. I guess we did.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Why don't you return this car and borrow mine? Have Debi follow you to the rent-a-car so you can get a ride back.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: I think I'll go see Debi today.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Of course you will.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: I can't think of anything to say to her that seems appropriate given I left and never said goodbye to her.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Take care of her. She's a keeper.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Yeah...

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: And a leader. Didn't she meet Castro on foreign exchange?

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: I have always thought about her and missed her.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Separate the wheat from the chaff and you've got the candle cat.

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Remember no matter how impossible your problems feel. I've known people without a chance in the world. And all of a sudden, they have lives. Time allows miracles. Let yourself breathe, son.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Mom...

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: "What's up doc/ what's cookin'?/ What's up doc?/ Are ya lookin'?/ Hey! Look out!  You're gonna hurt someone,/ with that old shotgun,/ Hey... what's... up... Doooooc...!/ We really mean it!"

Speaker: mary
Dialogue: Hey, you're a handsome devil. What's your name?

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Hey Pop... You got off easy. The house is a 7-11. Mom's a psycho- pharmacological punching bag and I murder for cash. If you were here I think you'd be proud.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: pries out a wall vent, slides in the case and replaces the vent.

Speaker: mccullers
Dialogue: "...Against the wind... just a young man running... Against the wind... let the cowboy's ride!... Blame on it the thuuunder! Night moves..."

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: WRFN playing all vinyl, all the time. Oldies from the eighties. That was ah... the Specials. Doing... one of their songs...

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: ...and here's another.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: "Oldies from the eighties?"

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: I just play my own collection.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: It's nice to see you again.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: How long has it been?

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: Since you stood me up on prom night and vanished without saying a word?

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Ten years, I think. What I miss?

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: Well, let me see... they tore down the George Orwell monument and put up a bust of George Michael. Main Street's a four-laner, no left turns four to seven. I was married and divorced. And Grosse Pointe is now officially the new sister city to Lower Hutt, New Zealand. We have fiber-optic town meetings every two months.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Here is now there. There is here.

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: Those are the headlines.

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: Hold that thought.  No Pearl Jam. Call back in ten years.

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: Tell me about yourself.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: I'm in California most of the time. Traveling a lot on business. That's about it, really.

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: That's it?

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Not much else.

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: What's your business?

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: I'm a professional killer.

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: Professional killer. Do you get dental with that?

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Well, I'm in town for a few days, anyway.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Well, I gotta go. But I'll come back.

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: Okay.

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: A man comes to you. He is from the past bringing you pain long since put behind you. He says peculiar things and leaves abruptly. It all comes flooding back...

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: It felt like an apparition, or some cheap, gruesome Rod Serling time warp I'd been thrust back into without warning. There's a strangeness in the air and I don't mind telling you, I'm a little spooked. He was a man from my past. A man I loved. A man who disappeared.

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: A man who's walking back into the station.

Speaker: lardner
Dialogue: Well?

Speaker: mccullers
Dialogue: I don't think so.

Speaker: lardner
Dialogue: Well, remember when Frysal's men paid off the Deejay in Cairo to announce a bogus press conference in the --

Speaker: mccullers
Dialogue: --Nooo--

Speaker: lardner
Dialogue: --Yes. And the Munich Olympics in '72. A local radio station started broadcasting news of the massacre two minutes before it happened.

Speaker: mccullers
Dialogue: That's strictly Bader-Meinhof stuff.

Speaker: lardner
Dialogue: It was the PLO.

Speaker: mccullers
Dialogue: Whatever.

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: Sit.

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: All right mystery man. I want some answers. Let's recap. Spring of '84. Two young lovers with frightening natural chemistry. The girl sits in a seven-hundred dollar prom dress at her father's house waiting for the most romantic night of her young life. The boy never shows up, until now. So, what's the question?

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Where have I been?

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: More like what happened? What happened, Mr. Blank?

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: I don't know exactly. I could venture a guess but it would sound like a rationalization... I thought you know... maybe seeing you, some friends, my house... of course now a 7-11--

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: --Torn down in the name of convenience--

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: --and I guess, sure, seeing you would be part of that whole equation... I suppose the most important thing, really. I don't know. Anyway, this whole thing's my therapist's idea. It's my shrink, really.

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: Ohhh. You're in therapy too, Marty?

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: You see someone?

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: Uh, no. So you're back now, a decade later, and you want to sort things out with me. The question now is, do I allow you... access... to my being?

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: All right then. Would you like to share any more deeply personal thoughts with our listening audience before we go to our phone poll and see how the folks in radioland come down on this one?

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: Should a broken-hearted girl give a guy a second chance at love....

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: You're on the air.

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: Thank you caller.

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: You're on the air.

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Yeah....

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: Next caller.

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: Grosse Pointe Michigan, I hear you loud and clear: "If you love something set it free. If it comes back to you it's, well...

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: ...Broken...."

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Dammit. Never trust my instincts.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Here's five good ones!

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Marty! It's me. Paul.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Paul?

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: You're leaving me hanging here...

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Hey. Give me a break.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: This won't take but a minute. I just gotta hold their hands for a final walk-through. I'll take them in, get 'em out, then you and I can grab a little quality time.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Goddamn, It's good to see you. I was afraid you joined a cult or something. I half-expected you to come back to town in a fennel wreath and paper pants.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: There was no money in it.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: So what happened to you?

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Same thing that happened to you-- I stopped poutin' there on the sidelines. Got in. Got on the team. I joined the working week, you slick fucking asshole, so why don't you valet park your high horse and take it easy on your old buddy, Paul.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Fair enough.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: God it's great to see you.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: You too.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: So when are you authorized to use deadly force?

Speaker: southtec guard
Dialogue: Well, a 'course, taxes provide your basic service-- police and whatnot. But our customers need a little more than just that, you understand? This badge doesn't mean that I am a peace officer.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: So it's not a meaningful symbol, or anything. That badge is just the badge of your company. If I look suspicious on your customers' property-- well, under those heightened circumstances you have the authority to, ah... To shoot me.

Speaker: southtec guard
Dialogue: To shoot you. Correct.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: How did you get this job?

Speaker: southtec guard
Dialogue: Well, they were hiring, and it was only a two week course...

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Wow.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: ...What more can I say.

Speaker: husband
Dialogue: We'll talk soon.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: You'll be raising your new family in a work of art. A work of art in a work of art.

Speaker: southtec guard
Dialogue: I'm sure you'll be very happy.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: When my time comes, if it ever does, I want a beautiful, normal place like this... and a wife like you...

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: ...and you'll be safe here...

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Now. I don't make a habit of pimping my friends, but there is one prime little piece of land that you must see...

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: No. You drove us here.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Yeah, but it's still kind of eerie, isn't it?

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Ten years. What happened!?

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: I freaked out, joined the Army, worked for the government, and went into business for myself... I'm a professional killer.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Professional killer, huh? Does that come with a good HMO?

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: He sells BMW's?

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: He sold me this bad boy.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: How could you put your hard-earned dollars into the hands of the class bully?

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: He gave me a great deal.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Mein Dealer.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Hey! Bob! The car's running great.

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: Glad to hear it.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Bob...

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: It's me. Martin Blank.

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: Really...? So what?

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Okay. See you later.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: See you at the left-a-boy-came-back- a-man-made-good party.

Speaker: carl
Dialogue: Can I help you?

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: What's done is done.

Speaker: skateboarder
Dialogue: What the fuck, man?!

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Are you going to the reunion?

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: No. I'm not going. Is that why you're here?

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: That's part of it.

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: Well, you'll have a ball. You seem to have everything everybody wants when they go back. The car, the suit, the watch. The look. That just leaves the little things, like happiness, character, point of view...

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: It's always the little things.

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: Yep.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: I'm wondering how you've been. How you are. I'd like to catch up with you. If it's possible.

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: Okay. Let's catch up. You go first.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Well, there's not much to tell.

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: I'm sure you've done worthwhile things in the last ten years. You've had experiences.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Bad experiences.

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: You met people.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Bad people.

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: Watched television?

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Bad television.

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: Jesus. Marty. You're pathetic. It sounds like you need a Shockabuku.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: What's that?

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: It's a swift spiritual kick to the head that alters your reality forever.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: That'd be good.

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: What do you want?

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: I figured I could pick you up tomorrow around seven o'clock.

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: Let me get this straight, are you asking me out?

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: Unbelievable.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Seven it is.

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: I'll think about it.

Speaker: monty
Dialogue: Baby, it's eight o'clock.

Speaker: marcella
Dialogue: Thanks, Monty.

Speaker: marcella
Dialogue: Hey there, how'd it go?

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: It isn't done.

Speaker: marcella
Dialogue: This is not good.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: I'll do it tomorrow.

Speaker: marcella
Dialogue: What's it look like?

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: It's fine.

Speaker: marcella
Dialogue: You haven't looked at the dossier.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: I've looked at it.

Speaker: marcella
Dialogue: You have.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Yes. It's the same as usual. Nothing remarkable about it at all.

Speaker: marcella
Dialogue: I have to call the client and give them a reason why you're late.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Tell them my house exploded.

Speaker: marcella
Dialogue: I'll call them and tell them you're taking your time. Being a professional.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Okay, call them. Fine. Oh-- And if you could find out why they double- booked the job, and who is trying to kill me, and call me back-- that's be great.

Speaker: marcella
Dialogue: Will do.

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: Are you there?

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: Pick me up at my father's house at around seven. And don't be late this time.

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: Hello...?

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: This night, this reunion will be an important step in our relationship.

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: You're fucking psycho.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Don't rush to judgement until all the facts are in.

Speaker: mccullers
Dialogue: I wish he'd do his job already so we could do our job.

Speaker: lardner
Dialogue: We can't do our job unless he does his job.

Speaker: mccullers
Dialogue: Why don't we just do his job then, so we can do our job, and get the fuck out of here.

Speaker: lardner
Dialogue: Do his job? I'm not a cold-blooded killer.

Speaker: mccullers
Dialogue: Wait a minute--

Speaker: lardner
Dialogue: -Look. You want to kill a Good Guy, but not be a Bad Guy, you wait until a Bad Guy kills the Good Guy, and then you come in and kill the Bad Guy, and then you're the Good Guy.

Speaker: mccullers
Dialogue: So if we do his job, we're the bad guys. If we do our job, we're the good guys.

Speaker: lardner
Dialogue: Yup.

Speaker: grocer
Dialogue: moving into the diner.

Speaker: grocer
Dialogue: Easy, tiger.

Speaker: waitress
Dialogue: Hi. Welcome to B.I. McCafferty's. My name is Melanie and I'll be your server this morning. Let me tell you about some of our specials. Today we have the "Alfalfa on My Mind," our feature omelette. And there's our "Gatsby's West Egg Omelette." And if you're in the mood for something different there's the "I left my heart in San Franchezie."

Speaker: grocer
Dialogue: I want two eggs poached, hash brown well-done. English muffin for the bread. And a coffee.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Whole-grain pancakes. And an egg- white omelette.

Speaker: waitress
Dialogue: What would you like in the omelette?

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Nothing in the omelette. Nothing at all.

Speaker: grocer
Dialogue: Come on, live a little. I'm sorry about the incident yesterday.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: No harm no foul.

Speaker: grocer
Dialogue: A little misunderstanding among my associates.

Speaker: grocer
Dialogue: I told them to kill you and they didn't.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Hard to get good help these days.

Speaker: grocer
Dialogue: But since we're both here, I think it's time to take a fresh look at our relationship.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: I didn't get into this business to have "associates." And I don't want to join your Goddamned union. "Loner-- " "Loner gunman." Get it? "On my own." That's the whole point. Why don't you become a cop, or something. You can drink coffee in the morning... with friends!

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Look, this is a one-on-one business... Every time you get to know people, bad things happen. If it'll make you feel any better, this is my last job. So what do you say we put our guns away and forget the whole damn thing.

Speaker: grocer
Dialogue: Fuck you! No scabs! From now on, everything's regulated!

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: No deal.

Speaker: grocer
Dialogue: Fine. But we're not going to let you do your job. Because we're gonna do it. And then, after we do your job, we're gonna do another little job...

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Is that right?

Speaker: grocer
Dialogue: Yeah-- after I shoot you through the fucking forehead I'm gonna fuck you in the bullethole.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Nice talk, Sugarmouth.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Hi, I'm Martin Blank, remember me? I'm not married, I have no kids and I'd blow your brains out if someone paid me enough... So how've you been? Where do you stand on The Issues? Are you Left? Right? Up, down, proud, shamed, blahblahblahblah--

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: Flowers. That's funny.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: As long as I get the laugh.

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: Here. Let me put these in some rubbing alcohol.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: You look beautiful.

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: Okay... Hold on...

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: I'll just help myself to a cocktail.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Good evening, Mr. Newberry.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: How are you? How's business?

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: How's that?

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: I took the other road. I'm more of a self-reflective young lion who does business with lead-pipe cruelty and goes home to drink light beer in milky-eyes isolation. I love sports and sex and have no real relationships with anyone. And you?

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Why not?

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: I'm a professional killer.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Do you want to get a drink first?

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: I think they'll probably have booze there.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Right.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: I'll just be a second.

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: Okay...

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: ...Well, I didn't kill anyone, but someone tried to kill me and the guy in the middle got killed. So if I see that guy again I'm definitely going to kill him, but I won't kill anyone else. Oh, except for the guy I was sent here to kill. I don't know...

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Saw my mom... I'm with Debi, and I'm on my way to the reunion.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Out Loud?

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: ...I am at home with the me. I am rooted in me, who is on this adventure.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: This is me breating.

Speaker: maritn
Dialogue: Alright, look. I gotta go.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Right. Don't kill anyone...

Speaker: lardner
Dialogue: He's falling for her. Look at him.

Speaker: mccullers
Dialogue: He using her.

Speaker: lardner
Dialogue: You're wrong. Look at his face.

Speaker: mccullers
Dialogue: One cannot love and kill.

Speaker: lardner
Dialogue: I love. I kill.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Shoulda brought my gun.

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: arlene
Dialogue: Welcome back! I'm Arlene Oslott- Joseph.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: I'm Martin Blank.

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: Debi Newberry.

Speaker: arlene
Dialogue: Marty, you haven't changed a bit!

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Don't say that.

Speaker: arlene
Dialogue: We had pictures put on, that way everybody knows who everybody was!

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Wonderful.

Speaker: arlene
Dialogue: So, what are you doing now?

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Whatever I can get away with.

Speaker: arlene
Dialogue: Isn't it cute. It's so everybody knows who everybody was!

Speaker: batender
Dialogue: What can I make you?

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Beer.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Hey, Ken. How have you been?

Speaker: ken
Dialogue: Hello Martin. How have you been?

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Not bad. You?

Speaker: ken
Dialogue: Hello, Bob.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Hey, Bob.

Speaker: ken
Dialogue: I'm an attorney. I'm with Moss, Brice & Fromeyer.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: That sounds pretty interesting...

Speaker: ken
Dialogue: Sometimes. I'm in divorce, mainly. Some property. Some personal injury.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Those all seem kind of related...

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Tragedy makes you thirsty.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Well... I have to take this over to Debi.

Speaker: ken
Dialogue: Here. Take my card. Wait a minute... here's a special one. For top-shelf clients.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Thanks.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: I don't know, Blank, all these fucking people, driving me crazy. Look at them over there, memorializing old times, acting all like it was something "life-changing." And the people in the National Honor Society? The name tags?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: They have special blue starts on them like it fucking matters now that they were in the honor club ten years ago. I'm getting fucking nauseous from all this sentimental bullshit. It's making me sick.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Why are you here... Terry?

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: I wanted to see a couple people. But I don't want to talk about the old days... What did we have together, Martin? Typing?

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Drafting.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Yeah, I couldn't stand that fucking class. But I appreciate you helping me out, man.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Don't mention it.

Speaker: terry
Dialogue: Yeah, thanks. Well I'm going to try and get out of here, man. I'll see you later.

Speaker: dan
Dialogue: Bob. Bob Destephano.

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: dan
Dialogue: I'm Dan. Dan Koretzky.

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: Computer guy.

Speaker: dan
Dialogue: Yeah... Hey, I saw you at your dad's dealership the other day.

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: I sell BMW's. What do you do?

Speaker: dan
Dialogue: Not much, actually. My software company just went public so I'm just... hanging out, really.

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: Remember high school?

Speaker: dan
Dialogue: Sure. Listen. Why don't you join us up in the grandstands?

Speaker: mike
Dialogue: ...You gotta hold the fans responsible, though, Dennis, because they're the ones putting up with the mediocre product.

Speaker: dennis
Dialogue: I guess, though, you know, if you look at it Mike, that park is a beautiful park, I've gone to that park many times - I've had the greatest time of my life at that ballpark and let's face it, I tell you this, Mike, by the sixth inning, if you're having the fun you should be having at Tigers Stadium, you don't even know what the hell's going on anyway...

Speaker: darius
Dialogue: Have you two been together since high school?

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: No--

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: --Yes. Actually we just bought that little Frank Lloyd Wright on Pine Avenue... Debi's a social worker and I mow down insurance claims at Aetna--

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: We haven't seen each other since high school.

Speaker: darius
Dialogue: I figured. You two look too happy together. I shouldn't say that though, I'm married... So, Martin-- what are you up to these days? What do you do for a living?

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: I'm in pro-active international relations. It's a very specialized company. We execute economic investment opportunities. Sort of economic clean-up... with an emphasis on personnel. It's boring, you know, it's boring. I don't like to talk about it because I don't think what a man does necessarily reflects who he is...

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: ...I've always tried to refrain from a black-and-white moral lexicon--you know, good, bad, right, wrong--I've been more interested in the gray areas.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: But that's no way to live. I guess you've got to just take the leap of faith. Believe in something. Fuck it.

Speaker: darius
Dialogue: Sounds complicated, Martin. Are you happy?

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: I just have to close this one last account. I'd like to just stop now, today, but I can't... It's a step in the right direction.

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: I don't know, Martin. It sounds like you're feeling compromised. Live the way you want. The only thing that's inexcusable, to me, is cynicism. That's the biggest cop-out there is.

Speaker: amy
Dialogue: But wait. I still don't understand what you do.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: I work at Kentucky Fried Chicken.

Speaker: amy
Dialogue: You do not.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Yes I do.

Speaker: amy
Dialogue: You don't...

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: In the corporate offices.

Speaker: amy
Dialogue: Oh... really?

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Yeah...

Speaker: amy
Dialogue: What do you do?

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: I sell biscuits to the Southland.

Speaker: amy
Dialogue: You do not.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: It's what I do.

Speaker: amy
Dialogue: You're so funny...

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: I sell biscuits and gravy all over the Southland--

Speaker: amy
Dialogue: --Stop it--

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: You know those horsey biscuit gravy packets? I move all of those--

Speaker: amy
Dialogue: --No.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Sometimes we sell them to McDonald's and just change them to special barbecue sauce.

Speaker: dennis
Dialogue: What do you think about black coaching in the NFL, Darius? Because I think it's great.

Speaker: darius
Dialogue: I don't pay much attention to football.

Speaker: mike
Dialogue: I have to agree with you Dennis. It's good to see that the owners are willing to put the franchise behind a black head coach or QB when for years in the league they've been kept out of the thinking positions and relegated mainly to the physical game.

Speaker: dennis
Dialogue: But now, you see, you have Warren Moon at the helm, Cunningham, Art Shell, and the coach up at Minnesota...

Speaker: mike
Dialogue: Dennis Green. And if you remember, Doug Williams was the first black man to prove that on a Superbowl Sunday.

Dialogue: I'm teaching art at Cedar Junior High School.

Speaker: dennis
Dialogue: ...Yeah, listen. Where do you stand on this whole Louis Farrakhan issue...?

Speaker: darius
Dialogue: I'm a De Klerk man myself.

Dialogue: I'm going over to play some tunes.

Speaker: dan
Dialogue: Look at her. There it is. Jenny Slater. The finest thing that ever walked these halls.

Speaker: dan
Dialogue: Yeah, he's around here somewhere. What a shame. She would have looked great in my fucking Bentley.

Speaker: dan
Dialogue: She's a paramedic in Skokie, Illinois.

Speaker: dan
Dialogue: You know what I'm really hoping? That Jenny Slater gets divorced. And she's twenty-eight--

Speaker: dan
Dialogue: She's twenty-eight years old, with two kids, she's still really really fine, and I see her at a bookstore or something, and she sees me for what I was then, and what I am now: the redemption for all her failure.

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: Which would you rather...?

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Okay... Would you rather... commit yourself sexually to a four-by-nine cell with former President George Herbert Walker Bush dressed as a super-model for a month, or make love to a otter on crank for a week?

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: Soft. I'll take the junkie otter, clearly! I'd let the little beast scratch and claw all he wants... Okay. Would you rather make love to the candied corpse of Phyllis Diller--

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: --She's not dead---

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: It's just a game...! Alright. Candied Diller, or... wear a hot pork vest across the desert with a fully digested crab apple in your mouth?

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Wow. I have to give this some thought.

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: No time.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Okay, then. Clearly candied Diller.

Speaker: stacey
Dialogue: Marty! Debi! How are you! So many people came, but I never expected to see you Marty. Or you Debi... I mean... because of what your divorce... I didn't mean to say that. I just meant you look so good.

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: stacey
Dialogue: Do you think you could play "Too Shy'" by Kaja Goo Goo?

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: Stacey, why don't you come up here and take over for a little while?

Speaker: stacey
Dialogue: I'd love to.

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: Everybody thinks they know me now that I'm divorced.

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: It's time to see you in private.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Even though I left, you never left me. Not just memory but a substance in my blood.

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: Like heroin?

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Too junky-kitschy. Deeper, deeper.

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: Like love?

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Could be. The physical substance of love.

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: I'll accept that. Follow me.

Speaker: mccullers
Dialogue: Looks like someone keeps trying to do our job for us.

Speaker: lardner
Dialogue: If he does our job, he's our job.

Speaker: mccullers
Dialogue: I get it.

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: I'll be right back....

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: So. You and Debi. Gonna hit that shit again?

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Fine, Bob. How are you?

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: Never better.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Really?

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: Ahhh... it's all fucked up. Nothing adds up to nothing... you work your whole life, day in and day out-- try to make sense of it all. One day you're twenty-seven and what do you get to show for it...

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: You could've been a contender, huh?

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: Smart boy. Real smart. Let's see how smart you are with my foot up your ass! I'm gonna kick your ass!

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Why would you want to hit me, Bob? Do you really believe that there's some stored up conflict that needs resolution between us? We don't exist. There's nothing between us. So who do you want to hit, Bob? It's not me.

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: What am I gonna do?

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: What do you want to do?

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: I want to be an actor.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Then express yourself, Bob.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Be honest...

Speaker: bob
Dialogue: Later, Martin.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Have you seen Debi Newberry?

Speaker: ken
Dialogue: Nope.

Speaker: ken
Dialogue: The more things change, the more they Goddamned well stay the same.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: I guess.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Take care of yourself, Ken. Thanks for the pen.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: What the hell happened to you?

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: I was catching up with Bob Destephano.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: As long as you had a good time.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: What now? Chase the girl?

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: It didn't work out.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: That's too bad.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: I have to get my head back into my work.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: Work's good for the soul.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: When you see Debi, tell her I'm sorry.

Speaker: paul
Dialogue: See you in ten years.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Dumb fucking luck...

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: He was trying to kill you, right!

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: Not the other way around...?

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: Is it something you've done?

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: It's something I do...

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: ...Professionally...

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: ...About five years now.

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: Get the fuck outta here.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Seriously, when I left, I joined the Army and took the service exam. They found my psych results fit a certain profile. A certain "Moral flexibility" would be the best way to describe it... I was loaned out to a CIA- sponsored program. It's called "mechanical operations." We sort of found each other...

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: You're a government spook?

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: I was, but no... yes... I was before, but now I'm not. It's irrelevant, really. The idea of governments, nations, it's mostly a public relations theory at this point, anyway. But I'll tell you something, until about five months ago, I really enjoyed my work.

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: Jesus Christ!

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Then I started losing my taste for it. Which usually means your time is up. But then I realized it was something entirely different... I started getting the sneaking, dark suspicion that maybe there was... meaning to life.

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: Okay. Great, Martin, that's just great. Meaning to life... Mmm....

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Like, that there's a point? An organic connection between all living things.

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: Let me help you along, Martin. You're a sociopath!

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: A sociopath kills for no reason. I kill for money.

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: You never could have kept this from me.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: I was leaving.

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: That's probably a good idea.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Will you come with me?

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: I'm staying here.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: What if I come back?

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: I'll hide.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Don't go.

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: You don't get to have me. You are a monster, I'm a human being. We're not going to mate.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: You don't understand...

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: That's because I speak human, and you speak monster.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: "What's up Doc? What's cookin'? What's up Doc, are you lookin'...?

Speaker: marcella
Dialogue: I'm bringing down the office now.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: I'll put things right. Then I'll find you.

Speaker: marcella
Dialogue: Uh... why?

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Don't worry. I left you a little something under your desk.

Speaker: marcella
Dialogue: All right!!

Speaker: grocer
Dialogue: Oh shit...

Speaker: newberry
Dialogue: What the fuck is the matter with you?!

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Well, I was hired to kill you. It's what I do, and come to think of it, I told you that, but... Okay. I'm not going to do it. Get in the car.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: It's either because I'm in love with your daughter, or because I have a new-found respect for life. Or both. But I don't know.

Speaker: grocer
Dialogue: That punk is either in love with that guy's daughter or he has new found respect for life... Let's go.

Speaker: newberry
Dialogue: Why? I build cars! They're paying you to kill me? Why?

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: It was a cost-cutting effort. They can't afford a recall.

Speaker: newberry
Dialogue: It was a leaky sunroof! A design flaw! I reported a leaky sunroof! You want to kill me because of that?

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: It's not me! Why does everybody think it's personal?!

Speaker: lardner
Dialogue: We'll go in through the woods.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: I was sitting in my house on prom night wearing that Goddamned rented tuxedo, a corsage in one hand, a bottle of champagne in the other. So I was just sitting there, and then the whole night flashed before my eyes, and it struck me like a bullet in the head-- I realized, finally, and for the first time, that... I wanted to kill somebody. So I figured because I loved you so much, that'd it'd be a good idea if I didn't see you anymore. But now I'm different.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: I'm in love with you. I know we can make this work!

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: I was afraid to commit to a relationship, but now I know I'm ready to make it happen.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: I just need time to change.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: It's not easy for me. I was raised to close off, to control my feelings...

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Lock the door.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: I wasn't raised in a loving environment.  But that's not an excuse. It's a reason.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: My soul was empty--

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: --and it's up to me to fill it.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: It's okay. It's Martin The door begins to open revealing Debi and Newberry.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: I know what I do isn't moral, per se, but if you could just look past that, you'd see a man worth loving.

Speaker: lardner
Dialogue: Did you see Blank in there?

Speaker: mccullers
Dialogue: No...

Speaker: lardner
Dialogue: Good. For a second there I thought we were in trouble.

Speaker: grocer
Dialogue: ...How about I sell you two rounds for a hundred grand a piece?

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: Okay.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: There you go. I left it blank.

Speaker: grocer
Dialogue: Excellent. Here they come.

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: This is WRFN Radio Free Newberry cause that's what it does. Bringing you New Ones for the Nineties, a fresh new format designed to pull you out of what's come before, and reel you into what's coming soon--

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: I tell you what's coming soon for me, or at least what I dreamed this morning in that weird time just before you actually wake up. But first this commercial. Back after this...

Speaker: announcer
Dialogue: Don't miss the show of the season at Bilkin Community Center! "Brigadoon!" A musical for all ages! "Brigadoon," starring Carol Plummer, Thomas Canchola, Bob Destephano, and Lee Ordman!...

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: RFN...

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: Hey out there... Okay... I'm going to finish up that fantasy later. First I'll give you an hour of nonstop music... If I don't come back on after that-- well, nevermind.

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: This will never work out.

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: You kill people.

Speaker: martin
Dialogue: I have no illusions about the future. What is, is. We make choices. And we become the sum total of our choices. I can live with that.

Speaker: debi
Dialogue: Other people can't.
